chapters.title: 1. Basics
chapters.description: Core concepts, terminology, and inventory basics.

questions.question: Which pricing model pays per 1,000 impressions?
questions.explanation: CPM (Cost Per Mille) refers to the cost per 1,000 impressions. 'Mille' is Latin for one thousand.

questions.question: Difference between Ad Slot and Ad Space?
options: Slot is container, Space is creative area
Slot is video, Space is image
Space is container, Slot is content
questions.correctAnswer: Slot is container, Space is creative area
questions.explanation: The Ad Slot is the specific space reserved on a website (container), while Ad Space is the actual area inside it displaying the ad.

questions.question: What does 'CPA' stand for?
questions.explanation: Cost Per Action (CPA) is a pricing model where the advertiser pays only when a user completes a specific action like a purchase or sign-up.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Network'?
options: Platform aggregating publisher inventory for advertisers
questions.correctAnswer: Platform aggregating publisher inventory for advertisers
questions.explanation: An ad network aggregates unsold publisher inventory and offers advertisers a consolidated pool of impressions, typically on a CPM basis.

questions.question: What is an 'Insertion Order'?
questions.explanation: An Insertion Order is a formal agreement between an advertiser and publisher that specifies the terms of an ad campaign.

questions.question: What is 'Fill Rate'?
options: Percentage of ad requests that are filled with an ad
Cost of filling an ad slot
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of ad requests that are filled with an ad
questions.explanation: Fill Rate is a metric that calculates the percentage of ad requests that are successfully filled with an ad (Impressions / Ad Requests).

questions.question: What is 'eCPM'?
questions.explanation: eCPM (Effective Cost Per Mille) calculates the revenue generated per 1,000 impressions, regardless of the buying model (CPC, CPA, etc.).

questions.question: What is 'CTR'?
questions.explanation: CTR (Click Through Rate) is the ratio of users who click on a specific link to the number of total users who view an advertisement.

questions.question: What comprises the 'Ad Tech Stack'?
options: Collection of software used to manage digital advertising
questions.correctAnswer: Collection of software used to manage digital advertising
questions.explanation: The Ad Tech Stack refers to the collection of software and tools (DSPs, SSPs, DMPs, Ad Servers) used to manage, run, and optimize digital advertising campaigns.

chapters.title: 2. Technology
chapters.description: DSPs, SSPs, and the tech stack components.

questions.question: What does DSP stand for?
questions.explanation: A Demand-Side Platform (DSP) allows media buyers to run advertising campaigns and buy inventory from various ad exchanges through a single interface.

questions.question: What is the primary function of an SSP?
options: To buy ad space for advertisers
To manage and sell publisher ad inventory
questions.correctAnswer: To manage and sell publisher ad inventory
questions.explanation: An SSP allows publishers to manage, sell, and optimize their ad inventory by connecting to ad exchanges and DSPs.

questions.question: Who uses an SSP?
questions.explanation: Publishers use Supply-Side Platforms (SSPs) to manage and sell their ad inventory.

questions.question: What does IAB stand for?
questions.explanation: The Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB) is responsible for developing technical standards and promoting best practices in digital advertising.

questions.question: What does ATD stand for?
questions.explanation: An Agency Trading Desk (ATD) is a unit within an advertising agency that provides programmatic managed services to brands.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Server'?
options: Technology to store and serve ads
questions.correctAnswer: Technology to store and serve ads
questions.explanation: An Ad Server is a web server dedicated to storing advertisements and delivering them to website visitors.

questions.question: What is a 'CMP'?
questions.explanation: A Consent Management Platform (CMP) helps publishers collect and manage user consent for data processing (GDPR/CCPA compliance).

questions.question: Who typically uses a DSP?
questions.explanation: DSPs are used by advertisers and agencies to buy ad inventory programmatically.

chapters.title: 3. Advertising Mediums
chapters.description: Channels, Formats, Video, Native, and DOOH.

questions.question: What is a 'Creative'?
questions.explanation: A creative is the file that contains the actual advertisement a user sees or hears.

questions.question: What is 'Native Advertising'?
questions.explanation: Native ads are designed to blend seamlessly with surrounding content by matching the design, format, and behavior of the platform.

questions.question: What does DOOH stand for?
questions.explanation: DOOH refers to Digital-Out-Of-Home advertising, such as digital billboards and screens in public spaces.

questions.question: What does CTV stand for?
questions.explanation: CTV stands for Connected TV, referring to television sets that can connect to the internet and stream content.

questions.question: What does MAID stand for?
questions.explanation: MAID stands for Mobile Advertising ID (or Mobile Device ID), a unique identifier assigned to mobile devices for advertising purposes.

questions.question: What is 'OTT'?
questions.explanation: OTT (Over-The-Top) refers to content providers that distribute streaming media as a standalone product directly to viewers over the internet.

questions.question: Which format is considered 'Rich Media'?
questions.explanation: Rich Media ads include advanced features like video, audio, or other elements that encourage viewers to interact and engage with the content.

questions.question: What is 'In-Stream Video'?
questions.explanation: In-Stream video ads play before, during, or after streaming video content (like a TV commercial within a YouTube video).

questions.question: What does 'Header Bidding' enable?
options: Simultaneous demand competition before ad server
questions.correctAnswer: Simultaneous demand competition before ad server
questions.explanation: Header bidding allows publishers to offer inventory to multiple ad exchanges simultaneously before making calls to their ad servers.

questions.question: What is 'Ad Verification'?
options: Ensuring ads appear as intended and detecting fraud
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads appear as intended and detecting fraud
questions.explanation: Ad verification services provide information about where ads appeared, whether they were viewable, and if fraudulent traffic was detected.

questions.question: What is the 'Waterfall' model?
options: Sequential ad calling usually by priority
questions.correctAnswer: Sequential ad calling usually by priority
questions.explanation: The Waterfall (or daisy chain) is a technique where the publisher's ad server calls ad sources one by one in a pre-defined priority order.

questions.question: Who hosts the First-Party Ad Server?
questions.explanation: A First-Party Ad Server is used by the publisher to manage their inventory and serve ads to their own website.

questions.question: What is 'Passback'?
options: Returning an impression to another system if unfilled
questions.correctAnswer: Returning an impression to another system if unfilled
questions.explanation: A passback (or default tag) sends the ad opportunity back to another system (usually lower in the waterfall) when the current partner cannot fill the impression.

questions.question: What is a 'Walled Garden'?
questions.explanation: A Walled Garden refers to a closed ecosystem where a platform controls access to its users, data, and inventory (e.g., Google, Apple, Meta, Amazon).

questions.question: What is 'Contextual Targeting'?
questions.explanation: Contextual targeting displays ads based on the content of the website page (e.g., shoe ads on a running blog) rather than user data.

questions.question: What is 'Audience Segmentation'?
options: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.correctAnswer: Dividing users into groups based on characteristics
questions.explanation: Audience segmentation is the process of dividing users into specific groups based on shared characteristics, behaviors, or demographics.

questions.question: What is a 'Look-alike Model'?
options: Targeting users similar to existing customers
questions.correctAnswer: Targeting users similar to existing customers
questions.explanation: Look-alike modeling uses data to find new audiences who share characteristics with your best existing customers.

questions.question: What is 'Brand Safety'?
options: Ensuring ads don't appear near inappropriate content
questions.correctAnswer: Ensuring ads don't appear near inappropriate content
questions.explanation: Brand safety practices ensure that ads do not appear on web pages with content that is inappropriate or illegal.

questions.question: What does GAMA stand for?
questions.explanation: GAMA refers to Google, Apple, Meta, and Amazon, considered among the most prominent walled gardens in the AdTech ecosystem.

questions.question: What is 'Geotargeting'?
options: Targeting based on time of day
questions.explanation: Geotargeting involves delivering content to a user based on their geographic location, such as country, city, or zip code.

questions.question: What is 'Retargeting'?
options: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.correctAnswer: Showing ads to users who previously visited your site
questions.explanation: Retargeting (or Remarketing) is a strategy to serve ads to users who have already visited your website or interacted with your brand.

questions.question: What is 'Dayparting'?
options: Scheduling ads to run at specific times of day
questions.correctAnswer: Scheduling ads to run at specific times of day
questions.explanation: Dayparting involves scheduling advertising campaigns to run only during specific hours of the day or days of the week.

questions.question: What is a 'Viewable Impression'?
questions.explanation: A viewable impression is a metric used to ensure the ad was contained in the viewable space of the browser window and seen by a real user.

questions.question: What is a 'Conversion'?
questions.explanation: A conversion occurs when a user completes a specific goal defined by the advertiser, such as making a purchase or signing up.

questions.question: What is a 'Landing Page'?
options: Page where users arrive after clicking an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Page where users arrive after clicking an ad
questions.explanation: A landing page is a web page where users 'land' after clicking an ad or link, designed specifically to drive conversions.

questions.question: What is 'Viewability'?
options: Whether an ad was actually seen by users
questions.correctAnswer: Whether an ad was actually seen by users
questions.explanation: Viewability measures whether an ad was actually in a position where a user could see it, as opposed to just being loaded on the page.

questions.question: What is 'Invalid Traffic' (IVT)?
questions.explanation: Invalid Traffic refers to impressions, clicks, or conversions generated by bots or other fraudulent sources rather than real human users.

questions.question: What is a 'Pixel' in tracking?
options: 1x1 transparent image used to track user activity
questions.correctAnswer: 1x1 transparent image used to track user activity
questions.explanation: A tracking pixel is a 1x1 transparent image loaded on a webpage that triggers a server request, allowing tracking of user behavior.

questions.question: What is 'SIVT'?
questions.explanation: SIVT (Sophisticated Invalid Traffic) consists of more difficult to detect fraud mechanisms like hijacked devices or malware, requiring advanced analytics to identify.

questions.question: What defines a 'Bounce Rate'?
options: Users who return to the site
Percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page
questions.correctAnswer: Percentage of visitors who navigate away after viewing only one page
questions.explanation: Bounce Rate is the percentage of visitors who enter the site and then leave ('bounce') rather than continuing to view other pages.

chapters.title: 7. Media-Buying
chapters.description: RTB, Auctions, Deal IDs, and Programmatic.

questions.question: What is Real-Time Bidding (RTB)?
questions.explanation: RTB is a technology where ad impressions are bought and sold via an instantaneous programmatic auction.

questions.question: What is 'Bid Shading'?
options: Optimizing bid price between first and second price
questions.correctAnswer: Optimizing bid price between first and second price
questions.explanation: Bid shading is an algorithm used to pay less than the highest bid in a first-price auction, approximating a second-price auction outcome.

questions.question: What is a 'First-Price Auction'?
options: Winner pays the second highest price
Winner pays exactly what they bid
questions.correctAnswer: Winner pays exactly what they bid
questions.explanation: In a first-price auction, the highest bidder wins and pays exactly the amount they bid.

questions.question: What is a 'Deal ID'?
options: A unique identifier for a programmatic deal
questions.correctAnswer: A unique identifier for a programmatic deal
questions.explanation: A Deal ID is a unique number assigned to an automated ad buy, allowing buyers and sellers to identify a specific package of inventory.

questions.question: What is an 'Ad Exchange'?
options: A platform facilitating buying/selling of impressions
questions.correctAnswer: A platform facilitating buying/selling of impressions
questions.explanation: An ad exchange is a technological platform that facilitates the buying and selling of ad impressions between advertisers and publishers.

questions.question: What is a 'Second-Price Auction'?
questions.explanation: In a second-price auction, the highest bidder wins but pays the amount bid by the second-highest bidder plus one cent.

questions.question: What is 'Floor Price'?
questions.explanation: A floor price is the minimum price a publisher is willing to accept for their ad inventory in an auction.

questions.question: What is 'Programmatic Advertising'?
questions.explanation: Programmatic advertising is the automated buying and selling of online advertising using technology and algorithms.

questions.question: What is 'Programmatic Direct'?
questions.explanation: Programmatic Direct allows advertisers to buy guaranteed inventory directly from publishers via an automated interface, skipping the auction.

questions.question: What is 'PMP'?
questions.explanation: A Private Marketplace (PMP) is an invite-only auction where high-caliber publishers offer their premium inventory to a selected group of buyers.

chapters.title: 8. User Identification
chapters.description: Cookies, IDs, Privacy Sandbox, and Clean Rooms.

questions.question: What are 'Third-Party Cookies'?
options: Cookies set by the website you visit
Cookies set by domains other than the one you're visiting
questions.correctAnswer: Cookies set by domains other than the one you're visiting
questions.explanation: Third-party cookies are set by a domain other than the one the user is visiting, typically used for tracking and advertising purposes.

questions.question: What are 'First-Party Cookies'?
options: Cookies set by the website you're visiting
questions.correctAnswer: Cookies set by the website you're visiting
questions.explanation: First-party cookies are created and stored by the website domain that the user is directly visiting.

questions.question: What is a 'Universal ID'?
questions.explanation: Universal IDs are identifier solutions designed to work across different websites and platforms, often as an alternative to third-party cookies.

questions.question: What is 'Fingerprinting' in AdTech?
options: Identifying users without cookies based on device/browser characteristics
questions.correctAnswer: Identifying users without cookies based on device/browser characteristics
questions.explanation: Fingerprinting is a method of identifying users by collecting characteristics about their device and browser configuration without using cookies.

questions.question: What is a 'Clean Room' in AdTech?
options: Secure environment for analyzing data without exposing raw data
questions.correctAnswer: Secure environment for analyzing data without exposing raw data
questions.explanation: Clean rooms are secure environments where different parties can analyze combined data without exposing their raw individual user data to each other.

questions.question: What is 'Privacy Sandbox'?
questions.explanation: Privacy Sandbox is Google's initiative to develop privacy-preserving alternatives to third-party cookies for online advertising.

questions.question: Which browser first blocked 3rd-party cookies by default?
questions.explanation: Apple's Safari was the first major browser to block third-party cookies by default with its Intelligent Tracking Prevention (ITP).

questions.question: What is 'ITP'?
questions.explanation: ITP (Intelligent Tracking Prevention) is a feature in WebKit (Safari) that reduces cross-site tracking by limiting cookie usage.

questions.question: What does a DMP mostly deal with?
questions.explanation: A DMP collects, stores, and organizes data from multiple sources to help with audience segmentation and targeting.

questions.question: What is 'Data Enrichment' in a DMP?
questions.explanation: Data enrichment is the process of enhancing collected data with additional attributes and information from various sources to make it more valuable.

questions.question: What is 'First-Party Data'?
options: Data collected directly from your own audience
questions.correctAnswer: Data collected directly from your own audience
questions.explanation: First-party data is the information you collect directly from your audience or customers (e.g., website behavior, CRM data).

questions.question: What is 'Second-Party Data'?
options: Data stored on a second server
questions.explanation: Second-party data is essentially someone else's first-party data that you access directly from the source through a partnership.

questions.question: What is 'Third-Party Data'?
options: Data aggregated from various sources and sold by vendors
questions.correctAnswer: Data aggregated from various sources and sold by vendors
questions.explanation: Third-party data is data bought from outside sources (data aggregators) that are not the original collectors of that data.

questions.question: What is 'Attribution'?
questions.explanation: Attribution is the science of assigning credit to marketing touchpoints that lead to a conversion.

questions.question: What is 'Last Click Attribution'?
questions.explanation: In Last Click Attribution, 100% of the conversion credit is given to the last touchpoint before the conversion occurred.

questions.question: What is 'Linear Attribution'?
questions.explanation: In Linear Attribution, credit for a conversion is distributed equally across all touchpoints in the customer journey.

questions.question: What is 'Time Decay Attribution'?
questions.explanation: In Time Decay Attribution, touchpoints closer to the conversion receive more credit than earlier ones in the customer journey.

questions.question: What is 'Position Based Attribution'?
options: First and last touchpoints get most credit
questions.correctAnswer: First and last touchpoints get most credit
questions.explanation: Position Based Attribution (also called U-shaped) gives 40% credit to first touch, 40% to last touch, and distributes remaining 20% among middle touchpoints.

questions.question: What is 'MTA' in measurement?
questions.explanation: Multi-Touch Attribution (MTA) is a measurement technique that evaluates the impact of each touchpoint across the consumer journey.

questions.question: What is an 'Attribution Window'?
options: The time period after an ad interaction during which a conversion is credited
questions.correctAnswer: The time period after an ad interaction during which a conversion is credited
questions.explanation: An attribution window (or lookback window) is the defined period of time after a user interacts with an ad for which a conversion will be attributed to that ad.

questions.question: What is 'Remnant Inventory'?
questions.explanation: Remnant inventory is inventory that a publisher has been unable to sell directly and is often sold for a lower price via networks or exchanges.

questions.question: What is 'Frequency Capping'?
options: Limiting how often a user sees an ad
questions.correctAnswer: Limiting how often a user sees an ad
questions.explanation: Frequency capping limits the number of times a specific user sees a particular ad within a given time period.

questions.question: What is 'Premium Inventory'?
questions.explanation: Premium inventory is the publisher's most valuable space, typically found on well-known sites, high-traffic pages, or highly visible placements.

questions.question: What is 'AdOps'?
questions.explanation: AdOps refers to the people responsible for setting up ad campaigns, trafficking tags, and managing campaign execution.

questions.question: What is 'DCO'?
questions.explanation: Dynamic Creative Optimization (DCO) is a process where advertisers show personalized ads to individual users based on information known about them.

questions.question: What is 'Budget Pacing'?
options: Spending budget as fast as possible
Distributing budget evenly over campaign duration
questions.correctAnswer: Distributing budget evenly over campaign duration
questions.explanation: Budget pacing (or distribution) is the strategy of spreading ad spend evenly across the campaign duration to avoid spending the entire budget too quickly.

questions.question: Why would a company build their own Ad Tech stack?
options: To have full control over data and customisation
questions.correctAnswer: To have full control over data and customisation
questions.explanation: Companies build their own stack (in-housing) to gain transparency, control over proprietary data, and customization that off-the-shelf solutions can't provide.

questions.question: What is a 'Media Plan'?
options: A document detailing the strategy, budget, and placement of ads
questions.correctAnswer: A document detailing the strategy, budget, and placement of ads
questions.explanation: A Media Plan is a comprehensive guide to a campaign's advertising efforts, including audience targeting, channels, budget allocation, and timing.
